On Wed, 17 Sep 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> > Never, ever, ever? I can see why the System.out.println() is
> > redundant here, since the assertEquals will provide the actual
> > length of the vector on failure. But generally, when and where
> > are diagnostic messages in tests appropriate? Do you have a problem
> > with System.out.println() or diagnostic messages in tests in general?
>
> They're like comments. Comments are not executable and cannot fail if
> they are wrong, so they are waste.

So code should never be commented??  This makes no sense.

>                                    Diagnostic messages are not
> assertions and cannot fail if they are wrong, so they are waste.

It is trivially easy to put diagnostic messages inside an if -- you
see them if something of interest occurs.

>                                                                 Make an
> assertion instead.

Usually.  But sometimes what you want is a soft assertion -- if the
condition doesn't hold, let me know, but keep on going.  And JUnit
doesn't support that approach.
